Factors

Factors have the highest priority in expression evaluation. In addition to regular immediate values and identifiers ( â†’ Tokens ) , they include the following:

true and false

true and false ( True and False ) are treated as integer values with the values 1 and 0, respectively.

Avoid comparing true or false with other expressions. For example, instead of doing something like if(true != getBoolean()), write it as if(!getBoolean()). This is because in logical expressions, "0 is false" and "anything other than 0 is true," not specifically "1 is true." Furthermore, since TJS2 does not have a Boolean type, automatic type conversion between numerical and logical types does not occur.

void

void indicates "nothing." It is used in various situations to represent the absence of anything. It is different from null.
A newly declared variable (a variable to which nothing has been assigned) has this value.
When treated as a string, it becomes an empty string ( '' ). When treated as a number, it becomes 0.

It is recommended to use the === or !== (identity) operators for comparing void values.

null

null indicates that something is an object but "does not point to any object." It is different from void.
Attempting to access a null object will result in an error.
By using the incontextof operator to change the context to null, that function will be executed on the context of the location from which it was called.

Example:
    var objmethod = obj.method;
    objmethod(); // Executed on the context of obj
    objmethod = objmethod incontextof null; // Change context to null
    objmethod(); // Executed on this (i.e., the context at the calling position)

Infinity

Infinity represents infinity. To represent negative infinity, use -Infinity.

NaN

NaN represents Not a Number. NaN is a numerical value obtained when the result of a calculation is invalid, among other cases.

super

super represents the superclass of a class within its methods or properties. An error occurs if it is referenced outside of a class method/property or within a class that uses multiple inheritance.

global

global represents the global object. It allows access to variables declared outside of all blocks, classes, functions that are not class methods, and so on.


Example:
    var v;
    function test(v)
    {
        global.v=v;  // Set the argument v to the global v
    }

this

this usually represents the object itself within a class's methods or properties.
The "context" specified explicitly or implicitly at the time of the call is designated as this.

Function Expressions

You can write functions within expressions using function. Please refer to Functions.

Array Expressions

Using [ ], you can describe an object of the Array class on the fly within an expression. Please refer to the Array Class.

Dictionary Expressions

Using %[ ], you can describe an object of the Dictionary class on the fly within an expression. Please refer to the Dictionary Class.
